Well, I might just be the guy your looking for with this question.I attempted tx twice.. The first go round, lasted 7 days, and was EXACTLY as you described above.. I lost 10lbs in 7 days, vomited uncontrolably, even with Zofran.. Could not sit down, and nervously paced around everywhere. Body turned pale, and over all was just wiggging out!!! Doc ordered me off meds immediately, as he thought I had an allergic reaction. The sx's you are describing are not normal.My first go round was absolute hell, and I had no intention of attempting tx again. First round was with redipen, and 1000mg Riba.6 months later, I tried tx again, Pegasys/copeg.. Went 32 weeks without the slighest of sx's, and cleared.. I'm 8 months post tx, and still undetectable.I would recommend discussing tx options with your Dr IMMEDIATELY.. If you are unable to hold fluids and food down, your not doing any service to your body.. Talk to Dr about switching interferons.. Thats what did it for me.Best of luck

NEW YORK (Reuters Health) May 12 - Patients with hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection who are 40 years of age or older have three times the risk of developing type 2 diabetes compared with their uninfected counterparts, according to a report in the May issue of Diabetes Care."HCV is a diabetogenic agent that by means of increasing insulin resistance strongly predisposes infected patients to type 2 diabetes," Dr. Rafael Simo from Hospital Vall d'Hebron, Barcelona, Spain told Reuters Health. Dr. Simo and colleagues reviewed the available evidence concerning the epidemiological association between HCV infection and diabetes. Mike

I don't "have" to take shots but I prefer to. When I was first diagnosed I was on oral meds - I think it was Glucotrol or something like that. After a while I asked whether insulin might be a more benign approach than meds which, to my understanding, either inhibit the liver or stimulate the pancreas. At the time I researched this subject pretty thoroughly but I can't recall much of it now. Anyway, I am not over weight, my triglycerides are low & my cholesterol is very low (95 to 130) so I could pretty much eat what I want as long as my glucose is controlled. At the time I switched to insulin I was on TX and had a lot of nausea and couldn't eat hardly anything. I asked my doctor if I ate a donut in the morning and covered it with insulin would that be okay. He said it was better than not eating anything and voila - I was shooting insulin. This doctor was my PCP (of sourse, I cleared this with transplant too) and he asked if it would bother me to give myself shots. I almost laughed as I told him that I was shooting Pegasys and Epogen every week and that didn't bother me too much so I thought the baby insuln shots would be bearable. Can-do, I am tightly controlled - my average glucose reading is under 105 and I test at least 5 times a day and most days 6 or 7. I want to see my before meal # and my post prandial # and especially when I have drug changes or dose adjustments. I am probably considered compulsive about my diabetes but remember I got this after transplant and there was so much testing and meds taking that the diabetes just sort of fit into to the new regime that I had to adhere to. Boy, that was long winded. But I always hear people say "my diabetes isn't that bad - I don't have to take insulin". I cringe when I hear that because, generally speaking, diabtets isn't good or bad - it's either controlled or not controlled and I really don't care much how it is controlled as long as it IS CONTROLLED. That's my rant. Mike

question: A week and a half ago I started Peg-Interferon with Ribaviron treatment for my Hep C.  About 4 hours after the shot I began vomiting and had SEVERE headache.  My headache lasted for 2.5 days of severe pain and is still here but more in control, my vomiting lasted continously for 5 days.  I ended up in the E.R.twice for fluids.  My family had a meeting with me and told me they wanted me to discontinue treatment immediately and the E.R. doc told us that I was not having a normal reaction.  I still have not went back to work, and ate solid food for the first time today.  I also had severe weakness that was not due to a drop in blood levels as the e.r. did my blood both times I was there.Is this normal side effects?My hepatologist went over the side effects and I have read about the treatment as well, but she stated that all but a handful of her patients were able to work.  This leads me to believe that I hit the extreme end of the side effects as I was having trouble just going to the next room (bathroom) it would have been impossible for me to work.Thanks for any and all input.  I am struggling with making the decision to quit treatment, but if I can't keep the pills down then it makes my chance of responding so much lower with the side effects I don't think I would make it the 48 weeks.  I am not sure they would let me stay on it for 4 weeks based on my reaction to just one.
